8.37.text:
>>Frans Timmermans: Just about four years
ago, my son Mark said I should start reading

13.59.text:
fantasy novels. Now, I like reading, but fantasy
was not on my screen. But since he had previously

21.46.text:
introduced me to the brilliance of some music
I didn't know before, I thought I might take

27.58.text:
him up on this. You know, if Bob Dylan turns
out to be brilliant, I didn't know that but

32.37.text:
my son did. Perhaps some of these novels might
be nice.

35.29.text:
And he introduced me to a series written by
an American author called George R.R. Martin,

40.77.text:
"Game of Thrones," now a series on HBO. And
I want to use Game of Thrones because -- in

48.27.text:
my lecture today because Game of Thrones sort
of captures the Zeitgeist more than anything

53.93.text:
else I've seen. It's the perfect metaphor
for where we stand as a society. It is confusing.

59.45.text:
It's epic. It's about good and bad but it's
not black and white. It's about challenges.

67.52.text:
It's about good guys doing things that you
wouldn't expect of them. It's about bad guys

71.39.text:
turning out to be good guys. Sort of like
society in general today.

76.61.text:
And one of the catch phrases -- I'll use about
seven quotes in my 15 minutes from the series

82.05.text:
to try and say something about Europe.
One of the most important catch phrases of

87.41.text:
the series is "winter is coming."
And "winter is coming" in the series means

94.29.text:
a lot of different things to different people.
"Winter is coming" to some means, you know,

100.06.text:
"Hide because hard times are coming, we can't
do anything about it, and the only thing we

104.21.text:
can do is hide away."
For others, it means winter is coming. That's

108.14.text:
an opportunity to show how strong we are,
because we -- in this case, the Starks in

114.20.text:
the series -- we are wolves and wolves are
best when they are challenged and winter is

119.36.text:
a challenging time and will give us an opportunity
to be better.

124.86.text:
Whatever the response is to the phrase "winter
is coming," winter is coming is very much

129.53.text:
part of European society today because I do
believe that the social contract underlying

137.18.text:
European society since the end of the Second
World War has run its course and needs fundamental

144.60.text:
renewal.
For the first time in two or three generations,

150.00.text:
parents sense that their children will be
worse off than they themselves, and whether

158.16.text:
we are going to be successful as a society
depends on our response to that fact.

165.23.text:
Now, we tend very often to simply deny the
fact and simply say, "No, it isn't true. People

171.66.text:
are wrong. People are misguided."
But I think honesty dictates that we should

177.63.text:
say that, "Yes, indeed, this society has reached
such high levels that you need to consider

183.75.text:
the possibility of lower levels in the future."
And the response to that will determine whether

190.42.text:
we can maintain the social structure we believe
in, whether we can maintain the values we

195.08.text:
believe in, or whether we will manage decline
rather than shape the future.

199.85.text:
The second quote: "Fear cuts deeper than swords."
Now, this is something I see in my society

213.51.text:
and I'm sure you will see in many European
societies, but perhaps also in the United

219.84.text:
States; that it is not the actual fact of
things going wrong but the fear that things

226.65.text:
might go wrong that paralyzes political action
in society. Because in the Netherlands we

233.95.text:
have -- we are the second wealthiest country
in the E.U., just right behind Luxembourg.

241.32.text:
We have strong social fabrics. We have strong
social systems. But the fear that this might

247.40.text:
become unhinged dictates political -- the
political environment and dictates attitudes

253.26.text:
of politicians.
And here again, we need to answer this question:

259.02.text:
Are we going to manage decline or are we going
to shape the future?

263.72.text:
Third quote: "When the snows fall and the
white winds below, the lone wolf dies but

271.09.text:
the pack survives."
Here again, Europe is struggling with this

277.56.text:
tension between individualism and community.
Now, today, because of our individualism,

285.57.text:
we tend to highlight the importance and the
beauty of community, but I am a son of parents

293.23.text:
who, because of community, were stuck in a
place and were not allowed to go to university

299.91.text:
because they were coal miners. You didn't
do that as coal miners. The pits, that was

305.07.text:
your future. And if you were very brilliant
-- we're Roman Catholics -- if you were very

309.10.text:
brilliant, you might become priests. But nothing
else. That was also community. Community could

315.03.text:
be also stifling, and we've fought a long
way to get in a place where we are individuals

322.47.text:
and we are recognized as individuals, but
we need to redefine what community is in relationship

328.87.text:
to retaining our individual rights.
And Europe is really struggling with that

334.58.text:
and not having given an answer yet to that
challenge.

340.91.text:
Fourth quote: "Most men would rather deny
a hard truth than face it."

346.05.text:
Now, here we're at the core of the problem
in the E.U. today.

352.23.text:
There is something in European nature or perhaps
in human nature that whenever there's a problem,

357.64.text:
we can get rid of it by blaming somebody else.
Traditionally in Europe, we would blame the

361.33.text:
Jews or we would blame the gypsies or we would
blame some other minority group or foreigners

367.05.text:
or whatever.
Now, this is not always as fashionable as

370.33.text:
it used to be. Some parties still do that,
but others have found other people to blame.

376.00.text:
The E.U., for instance. Blame the E.U. for
everything and all our problems will be solved.

381.47.text:
I see this -- I use -- I'm not sure I can
say this here at Google, but I use Facebook

388.03.text:
>>Frans Timmermans: -- to just get a flavor
of what people are thinking about subjects,

392.33.text:
and somehow very often when something happens,
a tragedy happens, a human tragedy, whatever,

399.75.text:
the immediate response is to try and find
someone to blame. And the E.U. is always one

406.00.text:
of the targets for blame.
And I think that is silly. You don't blame

412.20.text:
the U.K. as a country for something going
wrong. You don't say that if things are looking

418.40.text:
down in the economy, "Why don't we leave the
U.K." -- well, some people in Scotland say

422.91.text:
that. "Why don't we leave the U.K. and all
our problems will be solved?" But here you

426.41.text:
say, "Why don't we leave the E.U. and all
our problems will be solved."

430.29.text:
Now, the opposite attitude is as silly as
this attitude. Frankly, the French president,

438.89.text:
not being able to reform his country at this
stage, not taking the steps he needs to take,

444.92.text:
giving a huge speech saying that if -- once
we create a European government, all our problems

450.39.text:
will be solved, is not much removed from Nigel
Farage's statement that once we leave the

457.70.text:
E.U. all our problems will be solved. You
know, you need to be -- to create an honest

461.92.text:
platform and just be honest about what is
necessary and reform will be necessary.

469.73.text:
Fifth quote: "A man who won't listen can't
hear."

474.97.text:
Now, this brings me to the point of how we
communicate in this day and age. If I look

482.94.text:
at my kids and the students I had when I was
a professor at university in Utrecht, people

489.17.text:
have -- what we did when we were young, we
were taught to find things. Finding things,

495.32.text:
the process of finding things when you were
studying, was actually part of your education.

501.53.text:
When looking for things, you found the context
and you zoomed in on what you needed to find,

507.32.text:
and this process was part of your education.
Now, thanks to Google, finding things is no

514.24.text:
longer the problem. You can find things within
a few seconds, just going to Google.

522.64.text:
But then contextualizing what you've found
has become more difficult. You know, the difference

528.94.text:
in the way my kids and my students operate
with this and we did is fundamental in the

534.77.text:
way society is going to operate in the future.
So I think their capacity to sort of skid

541.40.text:
over reality at incredible speed, combined
with our learned, acquired capacity to contextualize,

550.07.text:
should be part of the solution of today's
problem.

553.18.text:
We have a legitimacy problem in governance.
You have it in companies. Look at the debate

559.07.text:
on, "Yes, it is right, it is legal to evade
taxes, but is it moral to evade taxes?" This

566.50.text:
is something CEOs of companies will have to
face if they want to keep their customers.

572.81.text:
This is something politicians will have to
face if they want to continue to try and get

579.16.text:
support for projects that shape our future.
And I believe what is asked of politicians,

586.09.text:
what is asked of people who have responsibility
for management, is to contextualize, to know

593.40.text:
what you're talking about, and then to explain
what we are talking about.

599.16.text:
This time and age, which is much more about
eclectic seeking of solutions and not -- you

609.31.text:
know, when I was raised and when I was a student,
we tended to think in complete systems of

617.75.text:
ideology. You were either a socialist or you
were a conservative or you were a communist

621.95.text:
or you were whatever. But the system, the
complete closed system of ideology would provide

628.71.text:
a solution to the problem, and politicians
acted upon that.

632.91.text:
This is what the E.U. is still doing today.
Not engaging people in trying to come to collective

640.03.text:
solutions, but telling people what the solution
is. And whenever the E.U. comes under criticism,

646.60.text:
it will come up with very easy answers: "Yes,
but it makes so much money so you should be

650.85.text:
part of it."
I think there's an op-ed in a British newspaper

654.84.text:
today of British industry, of industrial leaders,
saying, "We should stay in the E.U. because

662.36.text:
it brings 3,500 pounds a year to every British
household." I guarantee you this will not

670.68.text:
win the argument for Europe. It will never
win the argument for Europe.

676.69.text:
Why are Euro skeptics strong today? It's because
they make a leadership argument, a moral argument.

682.57.text:
They say, "This is not the right way for us
to go. We need to go a different way." And

688.23.text:
instead of responding to that by saying, "It
is the right way to go, it is the only way

695.27.text:
to go, because only if we stick together,
if we create a stronger community of 500 million

701.42.text:
people, can we resist the forces outside of
Europe, can we engage with the future" -- if

708.09.text:
you don't put the argument that way, if you
come up with roaming tariffs, if you come

712.57.text:
up with certain percentages of income per
household, the argument will fail completely.

718.48.text:
I tried, believe me, in our referendum campaign
in 2005 in the Netherlands. We had our economics

725.71.text:
board analyze what the profits are for the
Dutch public of the internal market, and they

731.07.text:
came up with the fact that this would lead
to an extra month's salary for every individual

738.80.text:
household, and immediately I got emails from
people saying, "When am I going to get this

746.28.text:
>>Frans Timmermans: Which is a natural response
to such a statement.

750.42.text:
And I think that is not a serious way of talking
about this. And honesty also dictates.

757.32.text:
But we talk about the downsides of European
integration. But we talk about things that

761.86.text:
we'll have to show in terms of solidarity
with other people.

767.15.text:
Today is Europe is in a bad place not because
our economy is in a bad place. Our economy

771.45.text:
is strong. We have the best educated generation
in our history. We are at the highest level

778.53.text:
in our history. We've never seen so much peace
and stability in Europe in human history.

784.91.text:
So we are in a strong position.
We are only made weak because we are interpreting

790.09.text:
"winter is coming" as something that is terrible
and not something that is a great challenge

796.67.text:
to pick up on.
I do believe that if politicians start to

801.43.text:
talk -- and leaders in business start to talk
openly about the challenges, start to understand

809.52.text:
that political leadership is no longer about
ideology per se, is no longer about saying,

814.33.text:
"This is what you need to do," but it is about
explaining what the complexities and realities

820.19.text:
are of today -- because if you start explaining,
if you start stating your case in terms of

827.28.text:
showing reality, people will engage, people
will talk to you, and people will know that

833.77.text:
we have a few limited options we can choose
from, and then you start talking to people

840.13.text:
about the options you can choose.
Europe needs to be doing that.

843.78.text:
Europe is doing all the things it should not
be doing. It's still in this pre-1989 mode

850.93.text:
of having an answer, even if -- even if you
don't have a problem, Europe will provide

856.40.text:
>>Frans Timmermans: That is a silly, silly
place to be, and it's a silly attitude to

860.67.text:
take. Europe should be honest about the fact
that we can't solve all the problems and should

866.01.text:
be honest about the fact that we can solve
the problems that will create a better and

870.45.text:
stronger society in the future.
Let me end with one of the nicest quotes in

876.70.text:
the series because I think it sums up everything
we need to think about today and tomorrow

882.41.text:
and everything we need to discuss. Very profound.
"if we die, we die" --
